characterList.description: An African American basketball player with a large beard. He plays for the Houston Rockets.
characterList.name: James Harden

content_metadata.description: An analysis of James Harden's career, focusing on his strengths, weaknesses, and unexpected correlations between his performance and strip clubs.

qAndA.answer: He plays for the Houston Rockets.
qAndA.question: What basketball team does James Harden play for?

qAndA.answer: Because he was a frequent visitor and spent a lot of money there.
qAndA.question: Why was James Harden's jersey retired at a strip club?
What statistical method did Ryan Sullivan use to analyze Harden's performance?
What city has the lowest average strip club rating, according to Ryan's analysis?
What is the correlation coefficient between Harden's performance and strip club ratings?

narrativeProgression.description: Explains Ryan's analysis using regression analysis to find a correlation between strip club ratings and Harden's performance.
Ryan defines 'subpar performances' and 'very subpar games.'
Ryan determines average strip club ratings in different cities.
Correlation coefficient is found to be 0.4575, indicating a positive moderate relationship.
Harden's performances decline in cities with higher-rated strip clubs.
Harden plays best in Toronto (worst strip clubs) and worst in Miami (best strip clubs).

trimmingSuggestions.description: The footage of the child dancing in a club feels out of place and doesn't add much to the narrative.
The cartoon of a woman struggling with math could be shortened or removed. It adds a comedic element, but it might be considered unnecessary for some viewers.

timecoded_text_to_speech.text: James Harden is one of the most polarizing players in the league today.
He's one of history's greatest offensive talent, but he does have some glaring weaknesses
and we're not talking about his defensive game.
He doesn't show up when it counts, he gets tunnel vision, doesn't know when to stop shooting
and can be very indecisive at times.
But the biggest weakness that affects his game has been strip clubs.
Yes, you heard me right.
I said strip clubs and this has been mathematically proven.
It's no secret James Harden has a certain love for the arts of erotic dancing, let's
say.
His jersey a couple years ago was retired at a Houston strip club because of how often
he visited and how much he spent.
His love for these clubs run deep.
In an elimination game in the Western Conference semi-final, it was reported he was seen at one
of these clubs till 4am and to no surprise, he had a terrible game.
Shooting two for 11 from the field and 80 his team, two for 40 point blowout.
The question became, do strip clubs affect the level at which James Harden performs?
A redditor by the name of Ryan Sullivan set out to answer this question.
After Harden had another horrendous game against a Miami Heat, a city renowned for its world
class strip clubs.
My guy Ryan analyzed James Harden's performance in every NBA city for the past four seasons
and correlated it with, those cities reputation for strip clubs to see if there's any relationship.
He did this by using D6 stats and defining variables.
He defined subpar performances as games Harden performed below his season average and
very subpar games as games 20% worse than his season average.
Then he determined that average strip club rating by averaging the Google review rating
from the first 10 strip clubs that popped up in his searches in each city.
Now, this is where it kind of gets hard for people who haven't take statistics.
Ryan performed a regression analysis with the strip club data and James Harden's performances.
He found the correlation coefficient, which is a measure of strength between two variables
to be 0.4575, which is a positive, moderate relationship.
Meaning, Ryan found out to his statistical degree, Harden's performances declined in cities
with higher rating strip clubs.
This was further supported when it was found.
Harden plays his best at Toronto, the city with the worst strip clubs and places worst
at Miami, the city with the best strip clubs.
The takeaway from this analysis is the slow one of the greatest offensive talents we have
ever seen.
It's taken on orthodox approach.
Not hug is left side, but invest in your strip club.
Thanks for watching guys.
Be sure to tune in next week for a new video and don't forget to subscribe.
It really helps and turn post notifications on so you guys can watch the content as soon as it
drops. This is Irvier Ranks where we only talk about ball signing off.

youtube_description:
James Harden is one of the most offensively gifted players in the history of the league. He has seen a variety of defensive schemes and has been able to manipulate them like no other. But there has been one strategy that has consistently slowed Harden's offensive production. Daryl Morey would personally approve of this strategy if he wasn't with the Rockets. The analytics certainly support it. Watch the video and find out what it exactly is!




Link to Redditor who crunched the number and figured out this strategy:
https://www.reddit.com/r/nba/comments/dt0ucg/i_analyzed_james_hardens_performance_in_every_nba/?utm_medium=android_app&utm_source=share
